bibl.title: Telegram from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, May 27, 1941

div1.p: Hench is anxious about speaking at the upcoming unveiling of the Cornwell painting. He presses Kellogg for details about the event and the painting.

div1.head: Telegram from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, May 27, 1941
div1.opener:
Charge to the account of_________________________________$___________
WESTERN
UNION
1206-B
R. B. WHITE
PRESIDENT
NEWCOMB CARLTON
CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD
J. C. WILLEVER
FIRST VICE-PRESIDENT
Send the following telegram, subject to the terms on back hereof, which are hereby agreed to
MAY 27, 1941
MR. GEORGE A. KELLOGG 257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY N.J.
div1.p:
BEEN ANXIOUSLY AWAITING DETAILED ANSWER MY LAST LETTER BEFORE WRITING FINAL
DRAFT. DO YOU THINK IT SUITABLE MY BORROWING GENEROUSLY FROM MY LAZEAR DEDICATION
ADDRESS WHICH I SENT YOU? AM USING NEW INTRODUCTION DISCUSSING WYETH PAINTING WHICH
TAKES SIX MINUTES SPEAKING TIME. LEAVES ONLY NINE MINUTES FOR BRIEF SKETCH STORY OF
CONQUEST AND MEREST PASSING COMMENT ON ITS CURRENT SIGNIFICANCE. TELL ME FRANKLY
WOULD TWENTY MINUTES BE TOO LONG? PLEASE ADVISE WHETHER PAINTING UNVEILED BEFORE
OR AFTER TALK. ALSO WIRE WHAT SUBSIDIARY FIGURES FINALLY PORTRAYED IN PAINTING.
COULD I SEE YOU HOTEL CLEVELAND SUNDAY MORNING? WILL THEN HAVE MULTIGRAPHED COPIES.
